unnormalised: Mumbai, Oct 26, 2024 – The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has announced a revision in the repo rate, impacting the interest rates on housing loans offered by major banks. State Bank of India (SBI) and HDFC Bank have both indicated adjustments to their lending rates, effective 1st Nov 2024.
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty sixth, two thousand and twenty four – The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) has announced a revision in the repo rate, impacting the interest rates on housing loans offered by major banks. State Bank of India (S-B-I) and H-D-F-C Bank have both indicated adjustments to their lending rates, effective first November two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: SBI's new housing loan interest rate will be 8.75% p.a. for loans up to Rs. 30 lakhs, and 9% p.a. for loans above Rs. 30 lakhs but below Rs. 75 lakhs. HDFC Bank's revised rates are slightly higher, at 8.8% p.a. and 9.1% p.a. respectively, for the same loan brackets. These changes will affect both new and existing borrowers, with adjustments made to equated monthly installments (EMIs).
normalised: S-B-I's new housing loan interest rate will be eight point seven five percent p.a. for loans up to rupee thirty lakhs, and nine percent p.a. for loans above rupee thirty lakhs but below rupee seventy five lakhs. H-D-F-C Bank's revised rates are slightly higher, at eight point eight percent p.a. and nine point one percent p.a. respectively, for the same loan brackets. These changes will affect both new and existing borrowers, with adjustments made to equated monthly installments (E-M-I-s).

unnormalised: Industry analysts predict that this increase will moderately impact the real estate market, particularly in metropolitan cities such as Mumbai and Delhi. The EMI for a Rs. 50 lakh loan, repayable over 20 years, will increase by approximately Rs. 1,500 per month. Potential homebuyers are advised to carefully assess their repayment capacity before committing to a loan.
normalised: Industry analysts predict that this increase will moderately impact the real estate market, particularly in metropolitan cities such as Mumbai and Delhi. The E-M-I for a rupee fifty lakh loan, repayable over twenty years, will increase by approximately rupee one thousand five hundred per month. Potential homebuyers are advised to carefully assess their repayment capacity before committing to a loan.

unnormalised: Moreover, the RBI has mandated that all banks clearly display their effective annual percentage rate (APR) for loans, including all associated fees and charges. This directive aims to promote transparency and enable borrowers to make informed decisions. The maximum processing fee charged by banks will be capped at 0.5% of the loan amount, with a ceiling of Rs. 10,000 + GST.
normalised: Moreover, the R-B-I has mandated that all banks clearly display their effective annual percentage rate (A-P-R) for loans, including all associated fees and charges. This directive aims to promote transparency and enable borrowers to make informed decisions. The maximum processing fee charged by banks will be capped at zero point five percent of the loan amount, with a ceiling of rupee ten thousand plus G-S-T.

unnormalised: Borrowers are also reminded to check their CIBIL score before applying for a loan. A score of 750+ is generally considered optimal for securing favorable interest rates. Several online platforms offer free CIBIL score checks, allowing individuals to monitor their creditworthiness. Defaulting on previous loans or credit card bills can significantly impact one's CIBIL score and subsequently, the interest rate offered on new loans.
normalised: Borrowers are also reminded to check their C-I-B-I-L score before applying for a loan. A score of seven hundred and fifty plus is generally considered optimal for securing favorable interest rates. Several online platforms offer free C-I-B-I-L score checks, allowing individuals to monitor their creditworthiness. Defaulting on previous loans or credit card bills can significantly impact one's C-I-B-I-L score and subsequently, the interest rate offered on new loans.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the RBI has highlighted the importance of understanding the terms and conditions of loan agreements, particularly regarding prepayment penalties and foreclosure charges. While many banks have waived these charges for floating-rate loans, it is crucial to confirm this with the lending institution before signing the agreement. The fine print often contains crucial details that borrowers should be aware of.

unnormalised: The announcement has triggered mixed reactions from borrowers. While some are concerned about the increased EMI burden, others are optimistic that the revised rates will help curb inflation and stabilize the economy in the long run. Experts recommend exploring alternative loan options, such as balance transfers, to potentially secure lower interest rates. Ultimately, a thorough understanding of the loan terms and careful financial planning are essential for managing home loan repayments effectively.
